Award.AwardTitle: Materials World Network - Renewable Resource Thermotropic Polyester
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Inter-American Materials Collaboration involving New Jersey Institute of Technology (NJIT) and Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México (UNAM) will develop new backbone chemistries for very high performance fibers, films and plastics incorporating renewable resource monomers derived from common agricultural crops. It is expected that these materials will have the density of common plastics yet exhibit the strength and stiffness usually associated with metals. The basic building block of the proposed research is isosorbide, a glucose derived chemical (glucose is a common product of either starch or cellulose fermentation) which can be incorporated into the backbone of polyesters and other common polymers. These materials are expected to be renewable, load bearing, lightweight, environmentally friendly and energy efficient.

This project explores the science behind achieving very high mechanical and thermal performance in polymeric materials. The relationship between ordered polymer liquids (liquid crystal polymers) and high performance polymeric products is well established. This project will lead to new understanding of the relationship between polymer backbone chemistry, liquid crystal phase creation and liquid crystalline polymer performance. Specifically: this project focuses on:
The identification of new, controlled stereochemistry mesogenic and disrupting monomers from renewable resources
Increased definition of how backbone chemistry defines LC phase structure, chain interactions and entanglements, rheology and solid state mechanical properties
Amplification of how processing and annealing interacts with backbone chemistry to define LCP performance

The program builds a strong and sustainable program between UNAM and NJIT, providing a forum for scientific cooperation between the US and Mexico over a broad range of physical science and engineering area. This research provides an avenue for exchange of personnel ranging from senior faculty to high school students

POR.DRECONTENT:
It is generally desirable to have polymers derived from natural materials since it enhances their chances of being sustainable and biocompatible. In addition, it reduces the load on the petrochemical industry if the materials are bio-based. Isosorbide is a bio-based material derived from glucose. It is a chiral diol with complex stereochemistry. The two hydroxyl units, being in endo and exo positions with respect to the rings, have unequal reactivity. This provides the opportunity to tailor molecules of choice by selective substitution with different chemical moieties. This property of isosorbide was exploited in this research project to develop symmetrical and asymmetrical monomers. This research project involves synthesis and characterization of novel isosorbide-based monomers and polymers which can be used as biomaterials, plastics and fibers. Isosorbide based high performance mesogenic polyesters were developed from isosorbide attached to known mesogenic moieties like biphenyl and naphthalene. These polymers exhibit liquid crystallinity and are thermally stable to temperatures up to 300°C or above. In addition, monomers with isosorbide attached to short alkyl chains were polymerized with isosorbide itself to form all-alkyl polymers with potential biodegradability. The properties of these polymers depend on the length of the alkyl chain, but generally show a trend of low glass transition temperatures and thermal stability to about 150°C. Isosorbide based AB monomer, Isoidide-2-(4-carboxyphenyl)ether was also incorporated in PLLA, a previously known biodegradable polymer. Isosorbide-modified PLLA exhibits orientational patterns when observed underpolarized light, but no apparent improvement in thermal or mechanical properties were observed. Isosorbide based epoxy resins were cured using natural carboxylic acids andamino-acids as cross-linking agents to form thermosets that have a high affinity of water and swell up to form hydrogels. Isosorbide based materials have been used in pharmaceuticals and personal careproducts and are known to be generally safe and non-toxic. Cytotoxicity studies performed on the materials of this portfolio of isosorbide-based polymers are in agreement of the biocompatibility of most of these materials. Overall, isosorbide based polymers provide a versatile bio-based platform to tailor polymers for use in a variety of applications, including biomaterials and high performance plastics.
